item.title: Honkai: Star Rail - "Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight Golden Scapegoat Puzzle
item.description:
"Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight is a new sub-area of Amphoreus in Honkai: Star Rail version 3.3. Trailblazers' first step to this map is with Phainon and Hyacine during the "Poet, Speak of the Sky Through Me" Trailblaze Mission in The Fall at Dawn's Rise chapter.

The Golden Scapegoat puzzle is an exclusive puzzle that can only be found in Amphoreus. Trailblazers need to control their character to reach the altar and light up the location with its torches. Once the puzzle is completed, they will be rewarded with various in-game resources such as Stellar Jades, Traveler's Guide, Lost Gold Fragments, and so much more.

HSR 3.3 Golden Scapegoat: "Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight - Puzzle #1

The first Golden Scapegoat puzzle can be seen on the west side of the "Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight in Honkai: Star Rail . Teleport to the Arching BoneMech space anchor , and enter the door to the west. Afterward, activate the Shrine of Prayers in the room before rewinding the time of the nearby platform so you can cross the road. Follow the path to the southwest and walk past another movable platform to find the Golden Scapegoat on the stairs.

To solve the following puzzle in "Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight, tap the following moves first to reach the button:

  • Right, Right, Right, Right, Left, Left, Up, Left

After the past self appears, tap these to reach the altars:

  • Left, Left, Left, Left, Up, Right, Right, Right

HSR 3.3 Golden Scapegoat: "Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight - Puzzle #2

The second Golden Scapegoat is on the lowest floor of the east side of the fortress. Teleport to the Frontier Corridor space anchor , and follow the path to the east until you use an elevator to descend further. Once you get through the door and enter the room, activate the Shrine of Prayers and head south to use the Janus' Hidden Passage . From there, use the stairs to go to the lower level to reach the Golden Scapegoat.

Use the limited slots with correct moves to solve the Golden Scapegoat puzzle, which are:

  • Left, Left, Right, Right, Right, Right, Right

Then, you need to avoid your past self, or it will be considered a failure. Tap the following moves to reach the altar:

  • Left, Up, Right, Left, Up, Left, Left, Left, Left, Left, Left

HSR 3.3 Golden Scapegoat: "Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight - Puzzle #3

The last Golden Scapegoat puzzle in the "Fortress of Dome" Eye of Twilight is also on the east side of the map. Teleport to the Frontier Well space anchor , and use the elevator right beside it. Once you reach the lower level, head west to the edge of the platform.

Solve this Honkai: Star Rail puzzle by using the following strategy when moving your character:

  • Left, Left, Left, Right, Right, Right, Right, Up, Left, Left

Now that the first step is done, avoid the doppleganger and reach the altar with these moves:

  • Left, Right, Right, Right, Right, Right, Left, Left, Left, Right, Left, Left, Left, Left

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: Overwatch 2: All Street Fighter 6 Event Challenges & Rewards
item.description:
Overwatch 2 has established a tradition in which it teams up with another popular franchise from various other games, anime, and other media influences to create a crossover collaboration event. In these events, which usually occur once or twice per season, players will see several Overwatch heroes take on a 'cosplay' approach with new skins in the appearance of characters from the collaborating franchise. In addition to this, there will be a set of event challenges that players can complete for rewards with each crossover collab event.

Previous crossovers include the likes of My Hero Academia, Diablo, Transformers, LE SSERAFIM, One Punch Man, Cowboy Bebop , and many more. In Season 16, the mid-season patch launched a collaboration event with Street Fighter 6 , giving a large group of heroes new outfits, highlight intros, voice lines, and emotes referencing iconic SF6 characters and their abilities. As always, there are also challenges that players can complete for bonus player titles, player icons, XP, weapon charms, and more. Everything you need to know about the Overwatch 2 x Street Fighter 6 crossover collaboration challenges and rewards has been included in the guide below.

All Street Fighter 6 Challenges & Rewards in Overwatch 2

The Overwatch 2 x Street Fighter 6 crossover collaboration event will be available in-game for players to enjoy between the dates of May 20, 2025, to June 2, 2025 . During this time, there are nine different event challenges that can be completed for rewards, including Season 16 Battle Pass XP, sprays, player icons, weapon charms, and more.

Here is a complete list of every event, challenge, and reward in the Overwatch 2 x Street Fighter 6 crossover:

Challenge Name

Description

Rewards

World Warrior

Complete 8 challenges from the Street Fighter 6 event.

Street Fighter player title

Round One

Play 25 games. Wins grant double progress. Stadium games grant double progress.

Juri Kiriko spray

10000 Battle Pass XP

Round Two

Play 50 games. Wins grant double progress. Stadium games grant double progress.

Sigma voice line

10000 Battle Pass XP

Final Round

Play 99 games. Wins grant double progress. Stadium games grant double progress.

Widowmaker voice line x2

Raging Demon

Deal 30,000 damage with abilities. (Excludes total mayhem & co-op modes)

Hanzo voice line

10000 Battle Pass XP

Knee Bazooka

Use Ultimates 30 times. (Excludes total mayhem & co-op modes)

Guile Soldier: 76 spray

10000 Battle Pass XP

Kikosho

Complete 20 games queued as Support or All Roles. Winds grant double progress.

Chun-Li Juno spray

Cammy Widowmaker spray

K.O

Complete 20 games queued as Damage or All Roles. Winds grant double progress.

Ryu Hanzo spray

Dhalsim Zenyatta spray

Of Course!

Complete 20 games queued as Tank or All Roles. Winds grant double progress.

M. Bison Sigma spray

Blanka-chan weapon charm

item.title: Cookie Clicker: Best Dragon Auras, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Krumblor's Auras provide significant buffs tailored for different game stages, with Dragon Orbs allowing massive boosts.
  • Dragonflight multiplies CpS by 1111 per click during a brief window, appealing to active players seeking high rewards.
  • Reality Bending offers small bonuses to various stats without drawbacks, ideal for new players navigating Cookie Clicker's complexity.

Cookie Clicker is one of those games that appears to be very simplistic on the surface, functioning as a basic idler where the player generates endless amounts of cookies. After a while, however, the complexity really shows its true colors and demonstrates a level of depth that is far beyond anything anyone would expect. It's a game all about progression and strategy, and there are plenty of interesting builds and options when it comes to maximizing that cookie output.

One of these progression mechanics is Krumblor's Auras, each of which grants the player a substantial buff to their run, and each serves an individual purpose for different stages in the game. While some are more situationally powerful, there are a few that are significantly stronger than the rest and offer an overall better boost to the ever-expanding cookie empire.

8 Dragon Orbs

Extra Golden Cookies At A Cost

  • Description: With no buffs and no golden cookies on screen, selling one's most powerful building has a 10% chance to summon one.
  • Aura: Wish 10% chance

Dragon Orbs provides a strategic option for players who are willing to sacrifice their hard work on construction for a massive boost. Now, selling an important structure can feel pretty bad, but when the production of the cookies just isn't cutting it, this aura can help players push out of the lull and accelerate them into the next stage.

It does seem counter-intuitive at first and would presumably slow down progress, but the potential payoff that comes from activating it can bring more than enough positives to offset the cost. It's an ideal aura for the mid-game and a great way to really push the limits of what's possible in a game that is seemingly one-dimensional but quickly shows how much more content there is in store.

7 Dragonflight

Ridiculous Cookie Multiplication With Every Click

  • Description: Golden Cookies May Trigger A Dragonflight
  • Aura: 19.25% chance of pooling

Golden Cookies are already a massive boon whenever they crop up on screen, but giving each one a chance of being amped up to 11 makes this aura absolutely ridiculous when it goes off. A Dragonflight creates a brief window in which every click multiples the CpS by 1111, turning a single cookie into a massive injection in an instant.

It isn't the best idle aura by any means, as it requires constant attention and actual clicking to make use of, but for players who prefer to stay invested in interacting with the game, it is the perfect buff to give them an extra reward for clicking fast and staying active in a game that is otherwise considered an AFK farm.

6 Reality Bending

A Jack Of All Trades

  • Description: One-tenth of every other combined dragon aura
  • Aura: ~1.02x to all effects

Reality Bending is one of those buffs that never feels exciting to play with, but the power it has in the background is still pretty immense and hard to challenge. A buff to different stats across the board, with no downside built in, means that players can happily pick up this aura and not worry about potentially harming any of the growth and slowly reap the rewards that will grow and grow over time.

It is among the most consistent auras in the game, providing a simplistic set of bonuses that always delivers but never blows anyone away. It's a great choice for newer players who are still familiarizing themselves with the systems and don't want to think too hard about optimizing to the level that the game can demand.

5 Supreme Intellect

Simple Buffs With Crazy Outcomes

  • Description: Confers various powers to one's mini-games while active.
  • Aura: Affects Garden (5% faster age/mutation), Stock Market (more chaotic), Pantheon (Jade=ruby, ruby=diamond), and Grimoire (10% cheaper spells, 10% higher fail rate)

A simultaneous buff to the side mini-games all at once, Supreme Intellect is a super-cool aura that creates a lot of synergies between multiple systems at once. Faster plants and more spells to cast, for players who really engage with all the mini-games to their fullest potential, it's the perfect choice, as having an extra reward for using them actively will mean that each one is suddenly significantly more worth using.

In the Pantheon, players can easily slot more spirits into higher tiers and amp up their effects to a pretty high degree, and with extra spells at their disposal, casts of Conjure Baked Goods or Hand of Fate are more common. This can lead to more windfalls and, ultimately, more cookies overall, thanks to this small but mighty aura.

4 Dragon Guts

Disgusting Yet Extremely Powerful

  • Description: Players can attract 2 more wrinkles. Wrinklers digest 20% more cookies and explode into 20% more cookies.
  • Aura: +2 wrinkles, 1.2x wither rate, 1.2x Wrinkler drop rate

Wrinklers are one of the stranger mechanics in Cookie Clicker and one that players will unfortunately have to grow to love, and by using this aura, the wriggling critters can become even more powerful than they already are. More Wrinklers means more multiplication and higher buffs on each one, allowing even a single pop to generate a huge bonus that feels unfair in its power.

The true power of the Guts comes during extended AFK periods, with more Wrinklers consuming more cookies and returning a significantly higher reward with each pop, allowing the player to return to a massive injection of cookies that is as gross as it is glorious. Now that the game is releasing on consoles, a whole new set of players will get to enjoy and recoil at one of the stranger mechanics in this humble clicker game.

3 Radiant Appetite

A Simple Multiplication That Gets The Job Done

  • Description: All cookie production multiplied by 2.
  • Aura: Cookie Production: 2x

Radiant Appetite offers the most straightforward but universally powerful effect of any dragon aura by doubling the entire cookie production just by selecting it. This clean 2x multiplier applies to every source of cookies, from buildings to clicks, making it consistently valuable regardless of the playstyle or game progression. The simplicity is also good for players who want to set down their phone for a while and not stress about specific mechanics while still building up their cookie count at a great pace.

The beauty of Radiant Appetite lies in its simplicity and reliability. While other auras might provide situationally stronger benefits, none offer such consistent performance across all gameplay scenarios. When the second aura slot is unlocked, Radiant Appetite almost always deserves one of those positions, complementing whatever specialized aura occupies the other slot. For pure cookie production without any strategic considerations, this aura stands unmatched.

2 Elder Battalion

Always Respect Your Elders

  • Description: Grandmas gain +1% CpS for every non-grandma building.
  • Aura: Multiplier = 1+(0.01(Number of buildings x Grandma count)

Elder Battalion creates a powerful feedback loop between the Grandmas and other buildings, granting Grandmas a 1% CpS boost for each non-Grandma building owned. In late-game scenarios with hundreds of buildings, this can result in Grandmas becoming exponentially more productive, often rivaling or exceeding the most expensive buildings in output despite their lower base cost.

This aura particularly shines when paired with Grandmapocalypse upgrades and a balanced building strategy. Rather than focusing exclusively on the highest-tier buildings, Elder Battalion rewards players who maintain relatively equal numbers across all building types and scales much harder than most other options in the aura department. When picked up in the later stages, the power is truly immense, and when built around properly, it becomes borderline overpowered.

1 Breath Of Milk

Multiplicative Feline Friends

  • Description: Kittens are 5% more effective.
  • Aura: Milk effect: 1.05x

Breath of Milk enhances one of Cookie Clicker 's core progression systems by buffing the cute little cats and continuing to function with each subsequent upgrade. It works super well into the end game, assuming that the player has accumulated high milk percentages through their achievements, and due to the multiplicative nature of the buffs, it becomes absurd further down the line.

Every kitten multiplies rather than adding, and the 5% compounds dramatically with each new upgrade purchased, resulting in a massive production increase with just a single aura. When combined with a second aura down the line, the power shows off even more and demonstrates that small buffs can quickly get out of control and lead to a monstrous level of production that few other systems can match.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: Blue Prince: All Upgrade Disk Locations
item.description:
Each player's experience with Blue Prince will be slightly different. This is in part because there is so much to do, and some of it is easy to miss, but it is also because you can choose which floor plans you want to add and which you want to upgrade.

There are a bunch of Upgrade Disks hidden all over the house, and you will need to look hard to find them all. This article contains the locations of every Upgrade Disk in Blue Prince as well as what they can be used for in this challenging puzzle game.

All Upgrade Disk Locations in Blue Prince

Inside the house itself and the outer rooms, you can find fifteen Upgrade Disks . There is also the possibility of purchasing more of these from the Trading Post outside the house, but you will have to trade items for them. Here are all the known locations of Upgrade Disks in the house in Blue Prince:

Room

Room Type

Location

Abandoned Mine

Underground

In the round room filled with candles.

Archives

Base

Inside a Filing Cabinet, the key to which is located in the Patio.

Basement

Underground

On a box by the elevator.

Commissary

Base

Can be purchased once.

Freezer

Base

Behind the frozen doorway.

Garage

Base

Inside the car's trunk; requires Car Keys.

Great Hall

Base

Behind one of the seven locked doors.

Her Ladyship’s Chambers

Base

Next to Her Ladyship's Diary.

Lost and Found

Found by digging

On one of the tables.

Mechanarium

Base

You need to have at least six mechanical rooms to get this Upgrade Disk.

Morning Room

Accessed by eating Bacon and Eggs in the Kitchen

On one of the tables.

Office

Base

On the desk.

Tomb

Base (Grounds)

Found inside one of the hidden locations unlocked with Burning Glass.

Trading Post

Base (Grounds)

Blow up the wall with Burning Glass.

Vault

Base

Inside Vault 304.

How to Get More Upgrade Disks

If you want more than the fifteen disks you can find around the house, you can trade for one at the Trading Post. You need to first draft the Trading Post outside in the Grounds, then you need to have Blue Prince items worth trading a disk for, like the Ornate Compass, the Emerald Bracelet, or the Master Key. It seems like the Trading Post won't give you access to more than one disk per day. Additional disks can be used to change the upgrade choices you have already made .

All Possible Room Upgrades in Blue Prince

There are sixteen total upgrades possible. Most rooms can only be upgraded once, but the Spare Room has two sets of upgrades; you will need to upgrade to the related secondary room to get to the upgrades beside it. Here is what all the upgrades will do for each of the rooms that can be changed in Blue Prince:

Original Room

Description

First Upgrades

Description

Second Upgrades

Description

Aquarium

Is every color of room.

Goldfish Aquarium

Is every color of room and gives you 10 coins.

None

None

Starfish Aquarium

Is every color of room and gives you 1 star.

Electric Eel Aquarium

Is every color of room and becomes a power source.

Billiards Room

Contains the Dartboard Puzzle in Blue Prince .

Speakeasy

Turns the Dartboard puzzle into one addition problem.

None

None

Break Room

End the day in this room to start tomorrow with the Keycard.

Pool Hall

Adds Great Hall, Foyer, and Secret Passage to today’s Draft Pool.

Boudoir

None

None

Bunk Room

Bunk Room

Cloister of Dauja

Cloister of Lydia

Cloister of Mila

Cloister of Orinda

Cloister of Rynna

Cloister of Veia

Corriyard

Her Ladyship's Spare Room

The next time you enter the Boudoir, gain 10 steps. The next time you enter the Walk-In Closet, gain 3 gems.

Spare Master Bedroom

Gain +1 step for each room in your house.

Spare Greenroom

Counts as a Green Room.

Spare Veranda

You have a greater chance of finding items in green rooms.

Spare Terrace

Green rooms do not cost gems to draft.

Spare Patio

Spreads gems around each green room you've already drafted.

Spare Hall

Counts as a Hallway.

Spare Foyer

Hallway Doors are always unlocked.

Spare Secret Passage

You choose Hallway (Orange), Red, Green, Shop (Gold).

Spare Great Hall

Has seven locked doors.

Store Room

Gain +1 Key, +1 Coin, and +1 Gem.

item.title: Blades of Fire Review
item.description:
Founded in 2002, Spain-based studio MercurySteam has quite the resume. While the studio is best known for its Castlevania: Lords of Shadow series, Metroid: Samus Returns , and Metroid Dread , MercurySteam has also released plenty of its own original titles over the years; however, Blades of Fire is the studio's first new IP in almost a decade.

Blades of Fire is a fantasy third-person action-adventure game with an incredibly unique spin on the Soulslike genre. But while its combat and originality are major strengths, there's too much that holds Blades of Fire back from greatness.

Blades of Fire's Story is a Mixed Bag

Blades of Fire sees players taking control of Aran de Lira, a grizzled warrior who's just been gifted one of the seven ancient Forgers' Hammers. With this godly tool in hand, Aran sets off with the young scholar Adso to take down the tyrannical queen terrorizing the land.

Blades of Fire 's story is solid. Though little narrative context is given to players at the start of their adventure, some intriguing twists, turns, and backstory revelations start to rear their head a few hours in. And while the narrative sinew joining these moments isn't very strong, some surprisingly emotional moments sprinkled throughout the game go a long way in keeping players invested.

That said, Blades of Fire 's writing and voice work don't do the game's serviceable story any favors. Though the performances themselves are fine, the implementation of voice lines can often lead to severe tonal dissonance, with characters making awkward jokes during an otherwise serious narrative sequence, or characters seemingly ignoring a vital story revelation moments after it's happened.

Additionally, many of the back-and-forth lines between Aran and Adso are repeated multiple times, which makes the story and its characters feel artificial. But much like other Soulslikes, Blades of Fire 's story takes a backseat to its gameplay.

Blades of Fire Has A Strong and Novel Gameplay Loop

Combat is by far Blades of Fire 's greatest strength. The game uses a traffic light system whereby enemies are given a colored outline when players lock onto them. A green outline indicates the enemy will take full damage, orange means they'll take reduced damage, and red means they'll take no damage at all.

As players progress through Blades of Fire , they'll encounter new enemy types that have specific resistances. Some enemies will wear armor on their body, which requires players to target their unarmored weakpoints using the game's directional attacks. Other enemies will be resistant to a certain damage type, such as slashing or blunt attacks, and thus require the player to use a different kind of weapon or weapon stance.

This constant moment-to-moment variation, along with responsive controls, unique and fluid animations for each weapon, and presentation touches like gory slow-motion finishers keeps Blades of Fire 's combat consistently engaging throughout the game's 30-hour runtime. Mechanics like the "Breath of the Defender" system, where players need to guard to regain their stamina, also do a great job of making Blades of Fire 's combat feel like a true evolution of the Soulslike genre.

But combat is just one half of Blades of Fire 's gameplay loop. One of Blades of Fire 's defining features is its Forge system, which sees players creating their weapons from scratch. Players choose a Forge Scroll blueprint, customize the weapon's various components and materials, and engage in a heating minigame that sees them trying to lower and raise metal bars to match the on-screen shape.

This Forge system takes some time to get used to, but after a few hours, the impressive depth of the system turns from overwhelming to engrossing. Blades of Fire 's Forge lets players manually adjust their weapon's parry window, block capabilities, reach, and damage. This level of player agency is rarely seen in a Soulslike, and it paves the way for a satisfying gameplay loop whereby players encounter a new threat, craft a powerful new weapon tailored to it, and use that weapon to engage in a thrilling duel.

This gameplay loop also encourages players to seek out the best materials they can find and unlock new Forge Scrolls, which feeds naturally into Blades of Fire 's level design.

Blades of Fire Suffers From Severe Pacing Issues

Blades of Fire 's world is split into a handful of distinct regions, each with its own set of unique, interconnected locations. These locations contain a wealth of optional pathways, most of which reward exploration by offering some genuinely useful upgrades. Players can find gems that increase their health and stamina, Criptexes that increase their healing flasks, and statues that award them with new upgrade materials for specific weapons.

Along with being rewarded for going off the beaten path, Blades of Fire encourages players to engage in every combat encounter they find themselves in, as new weapons are unlocked by defeating a certain number of a specific enemy type.

The very first area serves as the perfect example of Blades of Fire 's level design working as intended. The environment looks visually impressive, there's plenty of enemy variety, and players are rewarded for exploring. The critical path towards the next objective is also made clear.

It's in Blades of Fire 's third area that pacing issues start to rear their head. Levels quickly become a sprawling network of interconnected pathways that spiral erratically between different elevations. While this complexity can make levels feel lively and memorable, it can also make traversing them somewhat of a nightmare. This is especially true when the critical path is hidden behind something that otherwise seems optional, or a mechanic that hasn't been introduced before that point.

To make matters worse, Blades of Fire frequently tasks players with backtracking through these levels to find key items and open up new paths, which means the novelty of exploring these fantastical locations quickly wears off. The obtuseness of these levels isn't the only thing dragging Blades of Fire 's pace, however.

Blades of Fire Doesn't Nail The Soulslike Difficulty Balance

A high level of difficulty is often part and parcel of the Soulslike genre. Enemies hit hard, and players are forced to use their skills to progress. But there's a careful balance that needs to be struck to ensure that the player is challenged while not being discouraged. When it comes to most of its regular enemies, Blades of Fire understands this balance well.

Enemy variety is a core strength of Blades of Fire , with players being presented with a plethora of distinct visual designs and movesets throughout their adventure, most of which challenge the player in fair and unique ways. Blades of Fire 's boss design, however, isn't nearly as strong.

There are only a handful of boss fights in Blades of Fire , many of which repeat several times during the game. Though this repetitiveness is disappointing, it's far from these bosses' biggest issue. Many of these encounters feature standard attacks that kill the player in just one hit.

In other Soulslikes, a boss that can instantly kill the player is a sign that they need to go elsewhere and level up. But in Blades of Fire , that option doesn't really exist. While players can find various resources to increase their health, stamina, and number of health flasks, and can craft harder-hitting weapons, they can't level up in a traditional sense. And regardless of how many resources the player has found, these bosses will always be able to down them in just one hit.

This means there's no margin for error in these boss fights, which can obviously lead to some exceptionally frustrating deaths. This is especially true for physically smaller bosses who hit just as hard as their larger counterparts but feature a much faster moveset, making it nigh on impossible to read their attack patterns.

These boss fights eventually become mandatory and can end up taking hours for the player to conquer, thus dragging Blades of Fire 's pacing to a screeching and infuriating halt. Though the regular enemies that come before and after these boss fights are tough, their attacks are well-telegraphed and their damage output leaves some room for natural error. This juxtaposition only serves to make the boss encounters feel artificially difficult.

I played the entirety of Blades of Fire on "Steel" difficulty, which is the recommended setting.

In many ways, Blades of Fire is a trailblazer. Its core loop of thrilling combat encounters, rewarding exploration, and satisfying weapon creation and customization remains engaging throughout its runtime, and there are plenty of mechanics that push the Soulslike genre forward.

But Blades of Fire 's momentum is brought to an abrupt stop regularly. Artificial difficulty spikes and needlessly obtuse level design can lead to a lot of unnecessary frustration, and that frustration can quickly overshadow the game's greatest strengths. Blades of Fire had all the right materials in front of it, but it forged an uneven blade that keeps accidentally wounding its wielder.
